casebody.data:
The People of the State of Illinois, Defendant in Error, v. Mike McGuire, Plaintiff in Error.Gen. No. 6,334.

(Not to be reported in full.)

Abstract of the Decision.Intoxicating liquors, § 147*—when evidence sufficient to sustain conviction. Evidence held to sustain a conviction under the anti-saloon law for selling buck, aleo and cider, proved to be a malt liquor or intoxicating.Error to the County Court of Lake county; the Hon. Perry L. Persons, Judge, presiding. Heard in this court at the October term, 1916.Affirmed.Opinion filed February 10, 1917.Rehearing denied April 12, 1917.

Statement of the Case.

Prosecution by the People of the State of Illinois, plaintiff, against Mike McGuire, defendant, for violation of the act relating to anti-saloon territory. From a judgment for conviction under four counts, including a nuisance count, defendant brings error.

P. L. Jorgenson, for plaintiff in error.Ralph J. Dady and E. M. Runyard, for defendant in error; W. F. Weiss, of counsel.

See Illinois Notes Digest, Yols, XI to XV, and Cumulative Quarterly, same topic and section number.

 Mr. Justice Dibell

delivered, the opinion of the court.
